title: Wednesday, 14th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Off we go then! Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the typing and the numbers.

BE

BE

(Note: I don't know to whom I should credit that picture. It's from this BBC slideshow: http://www.bbc.co..../business-11849322 . If it's yours, just send us a note and we'll add the credit asap.)

11:05 am
BE

(I like it mostly because .... well, just look how low the ceiling is. If Melania tried to stand up, she'd brain herself on the electroplated cornice mouldings.)

BE

So .....

BE

(Bloomberg) -- Donald Trump leads Hillary Clinton 48%-43%
in a head-to-head matchup among likely voters in Ohio, according
to a Bloomberg Politics poll.

11:05 am
BE

omg smile

BE

* NOTE: Ohio is a critical swing state that has backed the winning candidate for president in every election since 1964

BE

omg smile omg smile

11:05 am
BE

* Poll finds demographic makeup of 2016 electorate resembles 2004 -- when Republican George W. Bush won re-election -- more than 2008 or 2012 races when the state and nation went for Democrat Barack Obama

BE

cry smile

BE

Now if you want more Trumping, you can read Frank Luntz on the media under-sampling of discontent votes: https://www.ft.com...-97ae-647294649b28

11:06 am
BE

And here's Roger Blitz to talk about what it might mean for cable: https://www.ft.com...-97ae-647294649b28

BE

Initial market reaction to Mr Trump taking up residency in the White House would be one of heightened uncertainty and risk aversion, HSBC reckons. Investors would sell the peso, while buying the havens of gold and the yen.

BE

Aye.

11:07 am
undefined
BE

So as to events, dear readers ..... We've a mini rally on.

BE

Of the "three days down, one day up" type.

11:08 am
BE

Miners largely.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 185.15, up 8.1 (+4.57%), High: 185.65, Low: 178.25, Volume: 20.53m
BE

Which I think SocGen is pushing this morning, though I forgot to drag out the note pre show.

11:09 am
BE

Pinned to the coal rally. One moment .....

BE

We nudge up our TP to 240p from 230p to reflect the solid financial
performance posted by Glencore in 1H16. Commodity markets remain
generally supportive, with zinc and nickel prices consolidating following a
rally and coal recovering after a four-year slump. We expect Glencore to
reduce net debt/EBITDA to below 2.0x by 2017e, which could allow it to
resume dividend payments as early as next year without compromising its
deleveraging objectives.

BE

Glencore reported solid 1H16 results The group’s interim results demonstrated
strong cost discipline in copper and zinc. Net debt was reduced to c.$20bn on a pro
forma basis, putting the end-2016 target of $16.5-17.5bn within reach even without
additional disposals. However, the absence of a major positive surprise, together with a
few minor setbacks prompted some investors to ‘sell into strength’ (share price -5%
since results day) with the stock up more than 110% since December.
Don’t follow the crowd We recognise that technical considerations may tempt some
investors to reduce exposure but think they would be ill advised to ‘follow the crowd’.
Glencore has the potential to over-deliver on deleveraging and resume dividend payments
as early as next year, in our view. We estimate the FCF yield rising from 10-11% in 2016 to
c.12% in 2017, on track for c.20% by the end of the decade, driven by: 1) production
growth, with copper, zinc and coal capacity restarts; and 2) a potential rise in copper
prices from $4,500/t next year to $6,000/t by 2021e as supply pressures abate post 2018.
Coal market recovery under way After four straight years of declining prices, coal
markets have finally entered recovery mode, providing an important pillar of support to the
stock. We estimate that a $10/t change in the long-term coal price translates into c.20%
equity upside, all else equal. While investors remain wary of the rally, stabilisation of
thermal coal prices at or above $60/t (largely in the hands of Chinese regulators, as we
pointed out in the previous report) could become a major catalyst for Glencore.
Valuation Our new TP is c.20% above the Bloomberg consensus, which shows a
consensus ‘Buy’ with positive ratings outnumbering negatives 3:1. Note that our valuation
does not factor in ‘stronger-for-longer’ coal prices as we stick to our (perhaps) conservative
$50/t FOB forecast post 2017 at this juncture. We think at least one more disposal could be
announced this year, cementing progress on debt reduction, although stability in base
metal/coal prices is paramount for improving sentiment and spurring a re-rating.

11:10 am
BE

So -- 2014, Glencore spends $1bn buying back shares.

BE

2015 - Glencore raises $2.5bn with an emergency rights issue.

BE

2017 -- Glencore restarts dividend payments?

11:11 am
BE

Sure. Why not. Master traders, these guys.

BE

Otherwise ............

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 814.00, up 30.2 (+3.85%), High: 817.00, Low: 786.10, Volume: 2.65m
11:13 am
BE

Couple of wee setbacks yesterday. Furnace runout at AmPlats and another 1bn rand bill from the SA taxman for Kumba. Neither seems to move the dial though.

undefined
BE

ROTR, I've seen some brokers push the likes of CRH on the idea of a Trump win .....

11:14 am
BE

.... because building walls takes a lot of concrete.

BE

No matter who pays for them.

BE

I note this idea rather than endorsing it.

11:15 am
BE

Anyway, what else do we have? Ocado day two, maybe?

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 254.14, down 23.86 (-8.58%), High: 274.10, Low: 251.50, Volume: 2.23m
BE

It's back to being London's most-shorted stock, incidentally. Nearly 25% on loan.

11:16 am
BE

Overtaken Sainsbury, which I think might be a consequence of the extra equity needed to buy Argos......

BE

..... So anyway, Andrew Gwynn at Exane turns negative on Ocado this morning.

BE

He reckons Ocado still has several years in the wilderness, making no money whatsoever

11:19 am
BE

Because though it already has sector-leading margins, it also has sector-lagging costs that just won't go away.

BE

And as he says: if Ocado can't make this model work, what chance do its potential licencees have?

BE

Here's the cover page.

11:19 am
BE

After a 14% fall yesterday, the question might be, have Ocado shares fallen enough after the group cautioned on margins yesterday? We think not.

Ocado cautioned that industry gross margin pressure is likely to drag earnings for the rest of the year. We'd say that is a known unknown however. What we think consensus will still miss is new capacity costs which will, on our estimates, mean Ocado will see next to no profit growth over the next 3-4 years. Our revised estimates were good to go ahead of yesterday's update - we just hadn't expected Ocado to warn on profit so explicitly so early.

Our new estimates leave us around 85% below current net profit estimates for 2017E. It's clearly a problem for Ocado, but also, it will complicate signing a new partner.

The most important line in our model is gross margin and we'd estimate that Ocado's gross margin is in the upper quartile of global grocers (on a comparable basis c30% versus an industry average near 27.5%). If Ocado is still struggling to make a profit, we think a partner will too.

What about bid speculation? Once again, we still think it is unlikely. Amazon for instance doesn't typically buy businesses - it creates them. We doubt that Wal-Mart will want much more exposure to the UK at present, despite recent press speculation. More generally, Ocado trades at 6 times book value and so it would always be cheaper to recreate the business, albeit slower.

BE

Now, my first reading of this was that the economics of delivering beans to folk only really start to work when capacity is flexible.

BE

As in, those using the Amazon Flex/Uber/Deliveroo model.

11:21 am
BE

And even if these firms are not providing a like-for-like service, their pricing will always be undermining Ocado's power to get customers to pay for the slack in its own model.

BE

But Andrew's argument is a lot more nuanced than that, with gross margin being at its crux.

BE

Ocado actually has a pretty good model ......

11:24 am
BE

Every product has to go from supplier to consumer. Shipping in bulk is the least expensive way of doing that but at some point you ‘break the pallet’ and start putting individual items in a box / bag. The problem in grocery is that you have lots of items going in a bag which demands lots of labour.

Breaking the pallet as near to the shopper as possible (the store pick model) helps bring down van costs (they travel less distance). The problem is, you end up touching the product more as you probably then need a national distribution centre suppliers can deliver in bulk to. So you end up with more labour cost – you’re maybe putting the product away twice and picking it twice.

Ocado only really has one DC between the supplier and shopper and these allows some automation to reduce the picking cost as they are big (a manual picker may pick 100 products per hour, some types of automation allow 500) but also reduce the number of times you touch products on the way to the shopper (you put it away once and pick it once). Higher logistic expenses are mitigated by shipping pre-picked orders to spokes (small depots) where you take the trays off a lorry and put them straight into a van. You also utilise vans better (small locations end up with more excess capacity – you can’t just buy one new van for the whole network in a store pick model but rather need one per location) albeit, they may still drive further.

So Ocado seems to have an advantage we think.

BE

However!

BE

However, the core problem is in food retail online, gross profit is low (compared to say clothing… 30% versus 50%) and cost to serve high (more than 30% versus c40-45%). Ocado is probably the most successful at bringing down cost to serve but really, it’s just the least bad. The group’s high gross margin means there’s break even… but for a partner, that might not be the case.

Where you could argue Uber / other competitors have an advantage is that they can charge a premium… a gross margin top up to compensate. This might be because the groceries come quicker, they might be skimming off profitable customers (they don’t order toilet paper and bottles of water), they might just be expensive. I’m not convinced those sorts of competitors are really mass-market however.

So if Ocado is struggling to make a profit despite its high gross margin, why would a competitor?

11:25 am
BE

Which, in the broader theme of the gig economy, strikes me as really interesting.

BE

Talk to Exane directly for the full argument.

undefined
11:27 am
BE

(@roddy1234: in part, I suspect that's true. They've also been a 50-year play on taking share from independent buy-at-the-wholesaler operators rather than each other, which has arguably left a very false impression of how competitive the sector has been in recent decades.)

BE

Okay, what else?

BE

Burberry sliding on the back of this rather cautious update from Hermes.

11:28 am
Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,259, down 15 (-1.18%), High: 1,274, Low: 1,239, Volume: 868.17k
BE

Hermes H1 fine, though mostly pre-announced in July.

BE

2016 guidance maintained but medium term targets abandoned.

11:31 am
BE

Having been steadily downgraded over the past couple of years. Went from 10% in 2014 to 8% in 2015, then "below 8%" earlier this year.

BE

Now, Hermes is already on 36 times 2016 so is a bit of an outlier for the sector.

BE

(Sector's on 20x on average.)

11:34 am
BE

Mostly on the idea that having a brand that appeals to CEOs and a reliance on leather stuff makes you less vulnerable to the vagaries of fashion.

BE

That thesis might we weakening a bit.

BE

Oh, and at the other end of the fashion market .....

11:35 am
BE

Good note out overnight from Morgan Stanley's Geoff Ruddell, pondering why people aren't buying clothes any more.

BE

As for a portrait, I guess we need to default to The next President of the United States of America.

BE

We are sceptical about arguments that
'millennials' don’t care about fashion and/or are prioritising 'experiences' over
'stuff'. We do, though, acknowledge the growing structural challenge of
increasing volumes each year to compensate for declining selling prices.

11:36 am
BE

In our view, however, the biggest issue may be a cyclical one: that there has been
a lack of 'newness' in fashion over the last couple of years, giving mainstream
consumers far less incentive than usual to update their wardrobes. Product
cycles have long been an important investment consideration in electrical
retailing, but we wonder if they are about to become so in apparel retailing too.

BE

It is now nearly ten years since the skinny-jean 'megatrend' began. We think it
likely that it will be superseded fairly shortly, though identifying the inflection
point may prove tricky, particularly for those of us more comfortable with
spreadsheets than mood boards.

BE

If our theory is correct, apparel retailers are likely to get a significant fillip in due
course. We think it may not be coincidental, however, that Inditex is currently
outperforming so significantly when fashion trends are so nuanced.

11:37 am
BE

I like this. I can understand this. The sector needs another big hit like skinny jeans.

BE

For those of us who missed out on the skinny jeans trend (or for whom jeans width is more of a necessity than a fashion decision) it goes on to quote a Washington Post article from February.

BE

"it helps to rewind to 2007, the year that the skinny jean arrived in many women’s closets and supplanted the bootcut style that had been a cornerstone of their wardrobes since the 90s. Now, think about all the other fashion changes that came with jumping on the skinny jeans bandwagon: Perhaps you bought knee-high riding boots to wear pulled over the jeans. Maybe you sprang for more flowy tops to give some balance to the body-hugging silhouette of the jeans. It was a major aesthetic shift, a moment when suddenly much of your wardrobe felt dated and in need of an upgrade. And while surely new trends have blossomed since then — athleisure, midi skirts, crop tops, to name a few — an outfit anchored around a skinny jean has been a constant for quite a while now."

11:41 am
BE

And .........

BE

BE

Makes total sense to me. Investors seem weirdly ambivalent about product cycles

11:43 am
BE

Geoff's suggestion to cure the sector's ills is for Kanye to start wearing flares.

BE

BE

Good, eh? I enjoyed it much more than I enjoy most analyst notes.

11:43 am
undefined
BE

BE

So .... I've been asked to tell you something.

11:44 am
BE

Izzy's doing a live chat thing about blockchain this lunchtime

BE

Because we now do live chats about a type of database, it seems.

BE

Next week, Janan Ganesh and Tyler Brûlé will discuss concurrency exclusion handling on SQL Server 2016 RTM.

11:44 am
BE

Maybe.

BE

If that's your kind of thing, here's the link: http://blogs.ft.co...eblogs/2016-09-12/

BE

Go entertain yourself for an hour with talk about the socioeconomic effects of cryptographic hash functions.

11:45 am
BE

Or do some shouting at clouds. Use the time how you wish, just as you do here.

BE

End commercial.

BE

11:46 am
undefined
BE

Rally seems to be picking up a bit. FTSE better by 0.7% now.

BE

We haven't mentioned Monsanto .......

11:48 am
BE

https://www.ft.com...-97ae-647294649b28

BE

$128 a share on the table.

BE

And a $2bn break fee in place.

11:49 am
BE

Out of interest, which set of shareholders benefits from that break fee?

BE

My reactive response is "neither", but I'm prepared to take other answers.

undefined
11:52 am
BE

Not long left, few things still to mention ......

BE

UBS selling HSBC

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 564.40, up 5.1 (+0.91%), High: 564.49, Low: 557.50, Volume: 16.29m
11:53 am
BE

Mostly valuation, and not working today clearly.

BE

HSBC's share price is up 17% in Sterling since early August results, adding US$25bn to
market cap and prompting increased investor interest in the stock and, given large
benchmark weights, FTSE100, Hang Seng and European banks too. This puts HSBC's
forward P/E at its highest level since 2010, a healthy premium to relevant peers such as
the Eurobanks sector and Citi. We see little in the operating environment and
conversations with investors to justify a further re-rating of the stock in the near term.

BE

Part of HSBC's re-rating is likely down to a recent surge in demand for the bank's stock
in Hong Kong from mainland Chinese investors via the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock
Connect facilities. Last week, southbound demand made up an average 38% of Hong
Kong volumes, peaking on Thursday at 56% of shares traded. As a firm we are not
negative on the outlook for a continuation of growth in Connect volumes in future. But
this week our China strategists turned more cautious on H-shares given the sector's
move and a number of near-term constraining issues.

11:53 am
BE

Actually, not selling. But not buying either. Just holding.

BE

We don't think HSBC is a Sell. Recent results confirmed progress on costs and sufficient
confidence on capital to confirm plans to pay a 51cps future dividend – a running yield
of ~5% net of scrip – and launch a US$2.5bn share buyback paid from the proceeds of
the Brazilian disposal. On the analyst call management suggested, we think, that
another buyback may be forthcoming if HSBC succeeds in releasing capital trapped in
the US since the Capital One sale in 2012. In a world of low yields and capital concerns,
we view decent income and non-UK exposure as attractive features of the stock.

BE

Despite the rally we see no basis at this stage to change our assumed cost of equity or
earnings estimates. This leaves HSBC at 11.3x 2017E EPS and with a 5.1% net yield. At
1.0x TNAV, HSBC is trading a touch ahead of our 9% forward ROTE. Our target prices
move only from FX changes to 540p HK$56 from 535p HK$54.6. With modest
capital downside offset by dividend yield we downgrade from Buy to Neutral.

11:54 am
BE

There's a Bernstein note around on HSBC too, even more cautious.

BE

For a bank that has 30% of its balance sheet exposed to the UK and is predominantly based in the South (the epicentre of Brexit), we find it interesting that the bank has had just 4% earnings revisions since the tail event - all explained by currency! We feel a mix of deleveraging, margin compression and risk takes HSBC's UK retail and commercial PBT down from $3.5bn levels to ~$1.5bn two years out – that's not in the Street's numbers.

BE

When Hong Kong slows down, it hurts HSBC the most and it is slowing down – which reads negative loan growth and rising risk. US rates up 25bps now is marginal given risk on house prices etc. GB&M like other IB peers bagged Q2 on Brexit volatility - H2 should revert down sharply. Overall margin squeeze on low rates, negative operating leverage and a sluggish IB environment should see EPS heading south of 50c.

11:56 am
BE

So, HSBC paying its divi out of capital with RWA migration and Basel IV still to come....

BE

... and Honkers deteriorating. Something has to give, is their argument.

BE

We see HSBC clocking sub 50c of EPS in the next few years. In that scenario, the bank will struggle to maintain a 100%+ payout ratio three years in a row. The dividend HAS to rebase eventually. The bank today is trading at 15X 2017 earnings. We rate HSBC Underperform with a Target Price of 350p.

11:57 am
undefined
BE

Oh, and there's a Redburn note out on Sky that I'd like to highlight.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 834.97, down 3.53 (-0.42%), High: 842.50, Low: 834.00, Volume: 655.51k
11:57 am
BE

........ But can't, because Redburn.

BE

Upshot is that with the endless bidding wars for football rights they're paying more for less.

BE

With a Champions League auction imminent.

11:59 am
BE

2016 already looks pretty rubbish and structural concerns are beginning to surface again.

BE

To that general thesis, I would note two things ......

BE

First .... ebay.

12:01 pm
BE

Want to buy an Amazon Fire Stick? You'll find 1.3k listings on UK ebay: http://www.ebay.co...ire+stick&_sacat=0

BE

Want to buy an Amazon Fire Stick that hasn't been sideloaded with software to watch movies and sport for free? Well, you'll find about 100 listings, tops. http://www.ebay.co...ick+-kodi&_sacat=0

BE

Also, head to the Google Play store and look at the most downloaded apps.

12:05 pm
BE

Riding high on the list is Kodi (a kind of open source media manager into which you can drop all sorts of stuff, much of it taking a rather fluid view of copyright legislation).

BE

To me, this all looks rather Napster-ish.

BE

It looks rather like the exact circumstances that knocked out EMI.

12:06 pm
BE

And I still struggle to understand why no-one's mentioning it.

undefined
BE

Okay, we're done. Comments dried up some time ago so I've no idea why I'm still here.

12:08 pm
BE

Head over to Iz's thing this afternoon, if you like. http://ftalphavill...bate-today-at-1pm/

BE

Or find us back here tomorrow.

BE

(@pfd: that was my initial assumption, but 1.5k Ebay listings suggests there's a market being served among numpties who can't work out how to sideload their Fire Sticks themselves.)

12:10 pm
BE

Cheers for the comments. Afternoon all.

BE

Over the last 12 months, the UK clothing market has underperformed other
categories of retail spending to an extent that we have never witnessed before.
We don’t believe the problem can be explained by weather, and note that a
number of other countries appear to be seeing something similar.
